titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Dined at Mr: Schickler’s. Several french emigrants there. M. de Maisonneuve the Abbé de Baliviere. Chevalier de Bressac, Chevalier de Villenotte an officer in the Russian service &c Baron Armfeldt was there too.— Took coffee in the Garden— Part of the Evening at the Casino.— Visit from Mr: Garlike with some late English Papers.— Hoarse so that I could not read.
2. Saw six Regiments of Infantry, about 15000 men, reviewed this morning in the park, by Marshall Möllendorf. Walk before dinner. At the Casino, in the afternoon. Thunder. Weather remarkably warm.

3. Baron Engeström, called upon me this morning, and communicated to me, his answer from Sweden— Nothing to be done there— Tis not lucky. Engeström too, is french.— Walk with Mrs: A. and afterwards.— Mrs: Brown and her daughters, and Miss Neale.— At the Casino.

4. Weather very fine, but warm. Walk with Mrs: A. before dinner. Letter to my mother— In the park alone in the afternoon. At the Casino towards Evening. Can now make out to read slowly and indifferently the German Papers. At home in the Evening. Blew the flute.
5. Continues warm. Walk with Mrs: A.— Afternoon long Walk in the Park. At Doctor Brown’s an hour in the Evening. My usual occupations continue, and employ almost every hour of my time.
6. Very industrious just now upon my study of German.— The customary Sunday morning occupation. Long walk in the Park.— Again towards Evening with Mrs: A.— At the Casino. French newspapers.

7. Fine and warm weather continues. The morning chiefly passed in settling accounts— Almost too warm to walk. At the Casino, this afternoon. Mr: Garlike called to see me in the Evening. Miss Neale & the Miss Brown’s at tea.

8. Letter from Baron d’Engeström— Wrote to the Secretary of State, and to Mr: Murray.— Party this Evening at Count Zinzendorff’s. It is really too late in the Season for Cards— Did not stay long. Walk afterwards in the Park. Mr: Garlike called here this morning.— Sent me the Irish Lord Chancellor’s speech on the 19th: of February, which I read.

9. Making an abstract from our Treaty with Sweden, this forenoon. Short walk in the Park; and in the Evening again with Mrs: A. Mrs: Brown, her two youngest daughters, and Miss Brühl walked with us.— At the Casino and read the last french papers.

10. Attended the special review of the infantry in Garrison, here, by the king. which entirely resembled that of the last week, by Marshall Möllendorf— Walk in the Park. Casino, after dinner. Shower, this Evening.

11. Went out this morning soon after 5, and saw the special review of the Cavalry of Berlin, by the king. There were two regiments of very fine men. There is nothing particular in the review.— At home making abstracts from our Treaty with Prussia, and reading Mirabeau upon the Prussian Monarchy.— Walk to the Fair, but overtaken by the rain. At the Casino in the afternoon.

12. Finished the abstract of the Prussian Treaty. Wrote a letter to Baron Engeström the Swedish Minister here. Walk in the Park. After dinner at the Casino. Reading German Papers.— In the evening finished the second part of Henry the 4th:
13. Sunday morning; our usual occupation— Wrote a few lines and walked.— Afternoon at the Casino. Both English and French papers. Late reading them— Home not till after nine.

14. Letter to Mr: King this morning.— Walk a short one. Evening at the Princess Henry’s party. Whist with Madame de Blumenthal, Madame de Saldern, and a dutch officer.— Home soon after nine. Mrs: A. at Mrs: Brown’s.

15. Finished reading the second, and began the third volume of the life and actions of Baron Quinctius Heymeran von Flaming, a German novel lent me by Baron Rothkirch, and which I read to acquire the habit of this language. translated part of Gessner’s first Idyll— Walk in the park after dinner with Mrs: A. At the Casino.

16. Weather very warm. Walk before dinner. Miss Neale, and the Ladies from Mrs: Brown’s with Mrs: A. in the Evening— Pass’d it myself at Count Zinzendorff’s— Conversation with Baron d’Engeström.— Boston Whist, with Count Stakelberg, the Chevalier de Villenotte, and Mr: Sievers, one of the Secretaries of the Russian legation.

17. Midsummer heat.— Letter to the Secretary of State.— Walk in the Park— Afternoon at the Casino— English and french papers. Upon my return home found Letters from Hamburg, Amsterdam, England & America. May hope to receive soon the new credentials.

18. Writing to my father.— Received the newspapers and pamphlets which came with the letters that arrived yesterday. All the afternoon reading them.— My German lessons will suffer in consequence of these interruptions.

19. Dined at Mr: Schickler’s. Party not very large. Upon my return home, found more packets from America, and among them the new credentials for the present king. To see Count Haugwitz to-morrow morning at 11.— Evening at Dr: Brown’s. Mr: Cortoys there.

20. Called at 11 to see Count Haugwitz: mentioned having received the new credentials, and had some conversation with him— He goes with the king into Prussia— Time only for a short walk before dinner. Mademoiselle Neale here afternoon and Evening. Half an hour at the Casino.

21. This and the two following days were destined for the grand annual reviews of the troops. I went this morning at about 4 o’clock. The review lasted till between 10 and 11. There were five regiments of cavalry of 1200 men each; and ten regiments of Infantry, of 2000 men each. The review is had, upon an open plain about two English Miles out of town— The troops are in admirable condition and exhibit a very fine appearance.— Upon my return found a message from Count Finkenstein, to meet him at 1. o’clock. Went accordingly, and delivered him a copy and translation of my new credentials. He told me that they would this Evening, make their report to the king, in order that if possible I might have an audience to deliver them, before the king leaves town for Prussia, which will be on Friday.— He said, Count Haugwitz had mentioned the circumstance this morning; having he knew not how received information of it, and they had determined to make their report this Evening.— Afternoon and Evening at home, somewhat fatigued.

22. Out upon the field again this morning between five and six. The reviews and manoeuvres were continued, but finished between 9 and 10, earlier than yesterday. On my return home visited Baron Alvensleben, to mention the receipt of the new credential to him. He said the king was so overburthened with business that it might perhaps be impossible for me to have the audience to deliver them, before his return from Prussia— Went to Mr: Schickler’s, and afterwards called upon Mr: Cohen, who has already moved into his new house— Went in the afternoon, to look at a carriage— Evening at home.

23. Third and last day of the reviews. Went between 4 and 5. It lasted till about ten; the representation this day was of the attack and defence of a place— The weather was extremely cold— Returned and wrote till dinner time. Afternoon and Evening, at Court. Ball and Supper given by the Queen upon her departure: at the Royal Palace— Company large. Mrs: A. presented to the king, and my brother to him, the Queen, and Prince Henry. The Evening long. Withdrew at 10.— Neither king nor Queen stayed to supper.

24. Called on Count Finckenstein at 1. P.M. He told me that the Ministers had made their report to the king upon the subject of my credential Letter, and that the king would with pleasure give me an audience to deliver it. But that he was at this time so crowded with business of every kind at the moment of his departure, that he was obliged, though reluctantly to postpone it untill the last of June or first of July when he should return from Prussia— I told him I should wait with Patience.— Dined at Count Panin’s, the Russian Minister— A very splendid diplomatic dinner, given to Prince Repnin, who has newly arrived. About forty persons at table; consisting, of the Ministers of State, Feld Marshalls and Generals, and all the foreign Ministers except of France.— Evening at Doctor Brown’s; upon returning home, found several important Letters and Papers.

25. Wrote this morning to Mr: Pitcairn, and Mr: Murray.— Received a number more of newspapers and pamphlets from America.— At the Casino in the Evening till past 9. Mrs: A. again unwell. The king left town upon his journey this morning. The Queen went yesterday in the afternoon.

26. Letter to Mr: King.— Wrote little else in the morning. Went to the play this afternoon to see Emilia Galotti; but before the first scene was finished, Mrs: A. was taken very ill, and fainted— We were obliged to return home. The Prince of Weilbourg lent us his carriage. Mrs: A. continued ill an hour or two after our return, but in the Evening was better.
27. Mrs: A. continues much better, and walked twice, in the morning and afternoon. Have an inflammation in my eyes.— Light thunder shower— Mr: Richards & Miss Browns a few minutes this Evening.

28. Called on Count Panin this morning, and had some conversation with him. On Baron d’Engeström whom I did not find at home— In the afternoon went to look at our new lodgings into which we enter, by the last of this month.— Letters from Mr: King, and from America. Evening at Dr: Brown’s. Mr: & Mrs: Cohen there.

29. Writing to my mother— Mrs: A. went in the afternoon to pay some visits— At the play.— Saw only a very short Comedy, called the Painter; and a long ballet.— The American in Spain. I find I can yet understand very little German, when spoken.— At the Casino— Closed the Evening with a walk.

30. Finished reading, the life and adventures of Flaming, a German novel in four volumes and began to read Archenholz’s history of the 7 years War. Find this much more difficult. At the Casino in the Evening, and read Herzberg’s life in the Nekrolog. Found the Miss Browns on my return. They go to-morrow to Charlottenburg.
31. Changed our lodgings, from the Brandenburg gate to the corner of the Frederic & Behren streets. A much more convenient house, but not so well situated. Day spent in making arrangements.
Day. Rise at 7. Read & study German till 10. Breakfast, dress and write till 2. Walk till 3. Dine, at the Casino till 8 or 9. then home & sup— Bed soon after ten.
